As opposed to mindless lyrics in the vein of Van Halen and AC/DC, Thin Lizzy's songs were mostly tales that were mostly interesting to listen to (though that's probably not the real reason you'll listen to one of their songs). Some of the songs don't instantly strike you as good, but with several listens one will begin to like them. Singer/songwriter Phil Lynott is a great choice for the band's style, and the musicianship is tight and pretty complex (they inspired many with their dual-guitar setup). It also goes through a good amount of moods and pacing - not every song is high energy like Van Halen is, for example. \\"Cowboy Song\\" is a good example as it starts off slow and eventually gets faster paced. Every track here is either good or excellent (and the hits \\"Jailbreak\\" and \\"The Boys Are Back In Town\\" definitely add to its appeal). I'll admit that it IS a guilty pleasure to an extent, but definitely not so much that most people wouldn't like it. Fans of the genre and music historians/collectors will most likely love it. If it weren't for its historical influence, though, I probably would've given it a \\"4.5\\". Highly recommended!    Highlights include:  the entire album!
0684824906|5.0|With \\"Team of Rivals\\", Doris Kearns Goodwin gives us an amazingly fresh and original view of our greatest president. As many reviewers have noted, writing anything new about Abraham Lincoln or the Civil War era is a daunting task - yet here Ms. Goodwin succeeds admirably.      The greatest value of \\"Team of Rivals\\" is the light it sheds on Lincoln's character and how it sustained not only him, but those around him as well.One is forced to conclude that Lincoln truly was our greatest asset during the Civil War. Without his leadership, it is easy to see how the Confederacy might have prevailed. With his leadership, we see how the Union always retained the upper hand in the struggle despite repeated setbacks on the battlefield.      As always, Doris Kearns Goodwin is a great story teller. Her enthusiasm for her subject is contagious. Most of all, she causes us to appreciate the nature of all forms of great leadership - something most essential in our republic.
B00000J6AG|5.0|Moby's \\"Play\\" is one of my favorite albums of all time. It's definitely my favorite electronica album, and there were so many hits (\\"Southside\\", \\"Run On\\", \\"Porcelain\\", etc...) off this album that it's easy to see why. Even the tracks which WEREN'T hits are extremely well done and very interesting. The lyrics especially are surprisingly good for this kind of album. Moby's voice isn't bad - I happen to like it a lot even if it's not necessarily for everybody. Every track here is fun and interesting which is ultra-rare (especially given the number of tracks). There's also a wide-range of emotions, pacing, and genres on display here - several of the tracks sound like they could be from a different artist or album. My personal favorites are \\"Run On\\", \\"Why Does My Heart Feel So Bad?\\" and \\"The Sky Is Broken\\" (this is a strange song for the album, but I like it). I think this is an essential album for ANY electronica fan and I would argue that non-fans of the genre would have a hard time disliking it. Moby struck gold with \\"Play\\"! Absolutely recommended!<br /><br />Highlights include:<br /><br />the entire album!

B00005B0PU|5.0|The 60's were indeed a great decade - SO many classics came out it's pretty staggering. The Zombies' \\"Odessey and Oracle\\" is but one of many timeless albums released in that decade, and it doesn't disappoint (though it's barely a classic). It's extremely accessible for most people and definitely fun and interesting to listen to (it also features the timeless hit \\"Time Of The Season\\"!). The singer is usually dead-on as a psychedelic pop singer - he has pretty good charm, although in some songs he's a little iffy (like on \\"Butcher's Tale (Western Front 1914)\\"). The harmonies on this album are notably great. The lyrics are unfortunately not all that great. Musically the album is also fantastic. This is primarily a psychedelic album, but it DOES cover a little R&B and pop rock. The audio quality is also very very good considering it was recorded in 1968. I'm pretty sure everybody can enjoy this album along with other classics like, say, The Lovin' Spoonful's \\"Greatest Hits\\". I think I would've given this a \\"4.5\\", but its historical influence, the classic \\"Time Of The Season\\" and all the bonus tracks pushes it to a \\"5\\". Highly recommended!    Highlights include:   the entire album (except for probably \\"Butcher's Tale (Western Front 1914\\")

B000BVQ9JO|5.0|Ok well I'm sure you are all wondering if The Strokes new album titled,First Impressions Of Earth,is worth your money. When the hype first started for this album,their were claims that this is very out there,and a way different strokes sound. Well not to burst your bubble,but if you're going in their looking for something to sound like Radiohead's Kid A,don't. It's rather a step in a different direction,that shows signs that next time will be a full jump. It is a different sounding strokes,but not as much as the hype. They definitely evolved their sound a good amount though. For instance,in \\"Electricityscape\\",they almost sound like a U2 cover band. Or on \\"Ask Me Anything\\" it's just a mellotron played by guitarist Nic Valensi,with singer Julian Casablancas singing over it. Or even songs like \\"Heart In A Cage\\",which is one of the more 'Strokes' sounding songs on the album,sounds evolved,with the guitars shredding away from Albert Hammond Jr.,and Valensi. One of the bigger differences on First Impressions is the drumming by Fab Moretti. On previous albums,he played the role as a Ringo Starr. Now he is a full throttle drum machine. Classic opener \\"You Only Live Once\\" shows off his skills,along with lead single \\"Juicebox\\". But with all good things,their is always something bad. And with First Impressions there are bad things. First off,Nikolai Fraiture's bass has just vanished,which is a disappointment considering that on previous albums it was key. Other than a few tracks such as \\"On The Other Side\\" and \\"Juicebox\\" the bass is really silent,which brings me to my next point. The production by David Kahne isn't the best. He does give the album a more clearer sound,but the all together package of production is so-so. Another fault,is the album feels out of place. It just seems they took songs and drew out of a hat for where each track goes. Other than opener \\"You Only Live Once\\",and closer \\"Red Light\\",the rest of the order could of been better. For example,on the last fivesongs(10-14) it's like watching Lord Of The Rings:Return Of The King. Out of those five tracks,three of them could of been closers. \\"15 Minutes\\",\\"Evening Sun\\",and \\"Red Light\\" are all contenders for closer,which \\"Red Light\\" wins.I like \\"Red Light\\" the most out of those three songs,but the other two fit the closer role better. For Julian Casablancas' lyrics,I actually like them. In the past he's always been an average lyricst,but on First Impressions,he is improved. Sure they're is the line \\"I've got nothing to say\\",which is a very weak lyric. I mean it's just lazy. But there are more good moments than worse. \\"Razorblade\\" features the line \\"My feelings are more important than yours.\\" That is one of the best lines I've heard in a while. Overall,First Impressions has pros and cons,but the pros outshine the cons by miles. The songs are just too good on this album. On \\"Red Light\\" Casablancas' states \\"The sky is not the limit,and you're never going to guess what is\\",and with The Strokes,I really wonder.
6305126062|5.0|For any one who is interested in the animal/human spirit connection, this is a film you mustn't miss. Robert Redford's direction of 'The Horse Whisperer' is a triumph. A deeply emotionally touching film, in which Redford also stars,it offers stunning scenery and cinematography as well as many beautiful layers of metaphor, symbology and juxtaposition. It's a film which explores themes of redemption and healing. Healing of both the human and animal spirit as well as the healing of broken relationships and families.   Grace's broken body and spirit (The result of a devastating riding accident, resulting in her best friends death) as well as her troubled relationship with Mother 'Annie',are beautifully juxtaposed with that of her badly injured and traumatised, beloved horse Pilgrim. The failing marriage of her parents,contributing further to the disconnection of the family unit, also adds another interesting layer to the film and plot.  Enter 'Tom Booker' reluctantly persuaded out of semi-retirement by the persistant Annie as the especially skilled and gifted horse trainer/healer (or 'Horse Whisperer' as legend has it), and who also becomes the catalyst in the bridging of the gaps between each member of this family in crisis.  Their time spent away from New York in the beautiful natural 'Montanna' setting with Booker(and family),along with Pilgrim's difficult and gradual journey back through Bookers 'healing ways', gives Grace the faith, confidence and inspiration she herself needs to regain her strength of spirit and will to overcome her physical obstacle. It also helps in offering a way for Mother and daughter to reconnect. Through Grace's traumatic accident and away from her familiar enviroment Annie's character is forced to re-think her life as the previously workaholic and somewhat controlling absent parent. The attraction and connection between Tom Booker and Annie obviously adds the obligatory Romantic interest, but more importantly it provides the final turningpoint for Annie's character, when she is forced to make a choice between her own quest for personal happiness and what is ultimately best for her daughter.  Kristen Scott Thomas (Annie) and a very young Scarlett Johansson (Grace) are superb in their roles. Sam Neill plays his small supporting role as the husband and Father, nicely and an although aging 'Robert Redford' is still convincing and ruggedly charimastic as Booker. The real star of this film however is Redford's direction and camera team. The film is so visually powerful; full of both subtle nuances and dramatic contrasts of light,darkness,sound and setting. Be warned there are some confronting scenes. As an animal lover I admit I found the graphically dramatic depiction of the horsing accident and Pilgrim's terror and suffering, quite unsettling and difficult to watch. The breathtaking Montanna scenery is a welcoming escape and contrast from the dark, synthetic and repressive New York City scenes. When Grace and Annie set off on their rambling long journey across mid-north America with horse in tow, the mood becomes one full of hope and adventure. Gradually too the characters regain hope and strength through this adventure and long journey of the human soul. In a sense they are reborn; revived by nature and the deep bond which exists between animal and human. That is ultimately what moved me the most about this story.  The critics as I remember didn't give this film its due when it came out. Many fobbed it off as some sort of sentimental, contrived 'Robert Redford Vehicle'. Far from it. It is an exceptionally well acted, well crafted, deeply moving and inspiring story and movie experience.

B000BGH22W|4.0|It is always difficult to review a film soudntrack, especially when all the other titles in the film series so far have been composed and conducted by the finest in the business, John Williams. Here, Williams steps down and is suceeded by Patrick Doyle. Now, Doyles high level of work is commendable, but I feel that he just can't deliver what the fans, and music lovers alike, have come to expect from Williams. Doyle uses \\"Hedwigs Theme\\" only minimally, and meddles with none other of the Williams 'Harry Potter themes'. Instead, as one would expect, he composes his own themes for various situations such as a romantic, melodic love theme for Harry, one or two beautiful waltz's, some wonderful fanfars and marches for different tri-wizard events and a new, immensely enjoyable and easily remembered theme for Voldemort. However, even with these musical treasures there is still a vast amount of room for improvement and expantion. Doyle injects emotion, tension, humour and downright scaryness into his music; worthy tracks are \\"Foreign Visitors Arrive\\", \\"The Goblet of Fire\\", \\"Harry In Winter\\" and the wonderfully dark and brooding track entitled \\"Voldemort\\". As I have said, this is not (in my opinion) the best of the Harry Potter film soundtracks but it is certainly a worthy entry. What follows is a brief description of each track: <br /> <br />1) THE STORY CONTINUES:  This track opens on a rythmic thudding by loud percussion, followed by a new motif (very dark in feeling), the track is finished with the use of \\"Hedwigs Theme\\". <br /> <br />2) FRANK DIES: Dark, brooding and scary music is played quietly, whilst the new theme for Voldemort is played over the top. Strings play loudly, and Voldemort's theme flourishes before an abrupt end. <br /> <br />3) THE QUIDDITCH WORLD CUP: Starts instantly with a cheery, Irish style jig which blends into a loud, rythmic chant underscored with dark music and choir.  <br /> <br />4) THE DARK MARK: Full orchestra plays loud, music; strings andbrass grow, before the first utterance of the new \\"Love Theme\\" is introduced. The track ends with a loud rendition of Voldemorts theme. <br /> <br />5) FOREIGN VISITORS ARRIVE: Hedwigs theme opens this track, followed by the love theme and two new motifs representing he schools of Beauxbatons and Durmstrung. <br /> <br />6) THE GOBLET OF FIRE: Voldemort's theme introduces this piece of music which quickly transforms into three fanfares as the wizards of different schools are chosen. As the Goblet belches a fourth name, Voldemorts theme is blasted out by the orchestra. The remaining fragments of the track use dark music to represent the current situation. <br /> <br />7) RITA SKEETER: This is a short track, that uses light hearted and quirky music to identify the character of Rita. <br /> <br />8) SIRIUS FIRE: Once more, dark and brooding music is used with hints of Voldemorts theme.  <br /> <br />9) HARRY SEES DRAGONS: Scary, high pitched music is used to demonstrate the effect of Dragon breath! <br /> <br />10) THE GOLDEN EGG: Classic Williams style action cues are used here, with a few terrifyingly string pieces; loud brass and percussion represent the flight of Harry and the Dragon. The piece finishes on a fanfare, followed by a great rendition of the Love theme. <br /> <br />11) NEVILLES WALTZ: The first of three \\"waltz style\\" consecutive tracks, two of which are used in the \\"Yule Ball\\" scenes. This waltz is, in one word, Magnificent. It is instantly memorable. <br /> <br />12) HARRY IN WINTER: This is the main theme of the new soundtrack. This is used in numerous tracks to illustrate Harry Potter, I have labelled it a \\"love theme\\" mainly because it is used to demonstrate the relationship between not only Harry and his parents, but also between him and Cho Chang. It is a beautifullly crafted piece of musc, and the album should, at the very least, be bought for this track alone. <br /> <br />13) HARRY'S WALTZ: This piece of music is fast and, for some reason, funny! After seeing the film, one can remember Harry's hectic footwork whilst at the Ball and this music illustrates the comedic value perfectly. <br /> <br />14) UNDERWATER SECRETS: Light, dizzy style music underscores the 'bathroom scene'. It utilises words from the Novel. Not an awful lot happens here though. <br /> <br />15) THE BLACK LAKE: Once again, rather like \\"THE GOLDEN EGG\\", this music is fast paced, loud and bombastic. It uses one or two fanfares but no new thematic material is present. <br /> <br />16) HOGWARTS MARCH: This is a great track. Doyle has composed a new, well, March for Hogwarts. It is short in length, but instantly memorable. It is played twice in the film, and it is a great listen. <br /> <br />17) THE MAZE: Dark, scary music is played from start to finish. It is loud, fast and at times, I found hard to listen to. <br /> <br />18) VOLDEMORT: In my opinion, one of the finest pieces of music ever composed for a film of any genre. Doyle outdoes himself, and has produced a 10 minutes composition that has to be heard to be believed. Like many tracks on the Album, it is dark and brooding, but there is a difference. Voldemorts theme is, as one expects, prevelant throughout. It slowly builds to a loud, bombastic brass \\"battle\\" style music, and only gets better with the albums finest, and also saddest, rendition of the new \\"love theme\\" as Harry and Voldemorts wands begin to entwine. <br /> <br />19) CEDRICS DEATH: A sad, short piece underscored with the \\"love theme\\". It illustrates beautifully the torture and emotion that Amos Diggory is going through after discovering that his son has been killed. <br /> <br />20) ANOTHER YEAR ENDS: This track is, like the love theme, beautiful in it's simplicity. Strings build to a triumphant ending as the schools of Beauxbatons and Durmstrang say farewell to Hogwarts. It is a wonderful ending to the film, and works equally as good as a piece of classical music. <br /> <br />21) HOGWARTS HYMM: Like the previous track, this music is wonderful. Somehow, Doyle has captured the spirit of the school in his composition and reveals it all in this final track. <br /> <br />22 - 24) VARIOUS SONGS: I have to admit, one of the reasons I disliked this score was for the last three tracks. They are, in my opinion, utter rubbish. Unlike Williams' \\"Double Trouble\\" which was magically brilliant, these three rock songs just don't deliver. They are loud, un-thematic and brings the listening value of the album down one star. <br /> <br />Despite my critiscm of the album and of Patrick Doyles work, I believe that change is for the better. Hopefully, should he return for \\"Order of the Phoenix\\" his work will feel more concrete and the sounds that we hear now will become part of the Harry Potter Music that we all know and adore. For anyone who likes the music from the series I highly recommend this album, but for those who wish to hear a sample of such music from \\"Pre-Doyle days\\" then perhaps \\"THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN\\" soundtrack would be more advantageous; it is, in my opinion, the best of the series soundtracks to date.

Your Song-5/5.  What can I say about this song that hasn't already been said?  Beautiful lyrics, great music and vocals.  His most well known song and one of the best of his hits. <br />2. I Need You To Turn To-5/5.  Elton used the harpsichord quite a bit on \\"Empty Sky\\" and he used it again on this song.  It fits the song perfectly.  One of the best songs on here. <br />3. Take Me To the Pilot-5/5.  A bit gospel-sounding with some rock and roll thrown in.  Great music and vocals with some of Taupin's best lyrics.   <br />4. No Shoe Strings On Louise-3/5. Elton would really make the grade with his next album \\"Tumbleweed Connection.\\"  However, the good songs on here are among his very best.
B000BYRCH4|4.0|You know Into the Blue is going to be beautiful, both the stars and the scenery. That's a given.<br /><br />The surprise is that this thriller is actually quite good, better than more ambitious recent efforts like After the Sunset. Even if Jessica Alba and Paul Walker aren't big names like Sunset had, the plot is tighter and more plausible -- skin-divers looking for buried treasure exposed by a recent hurricane in the Bahamas find it, along with a nearby crashed plane full of cocaine -- and the actors throw themselves into the admittedly not-amazing dialogue with real commitment.<br /><br />The only real issue in the movie is that Paul Walker is apparently half-dolphin, able to hold his breath for a half-hour at a time. The first time he does this, another character is impressed that he can hold his breath for three minutes at a time. Later in the movie, they're all doing a lot more than that, in areas where they can't conveniently get more air, and no one seems to think it's remarkable at all. There's also several uncontrolled ascents that scuba divers will wince as they watch -- several of the characters should be laid up with the bends at different points in the movie, and possibly have serious damage to their hearing -- but otherwise, the filmmakers show a generally strong understanding of diving, both scuba and otherwise.<br /><br />This is a light and breezy entertainment, to be sure, but a better use of your time than most such films. A strong recommendation for scuba diving movie-watchers, those who just love tropical locations and, of course, anyone interested in lots of sequences of Jessica Alba in a bikini.
B000BYA5GO|5.0|After sitting through (suffering through, really) the last installment of Star Wars and the recent King Kong, with all their excessive CGI, poor character development and bad acting, I had the unexpected pleasure of seeing Lord of War on pay-per-view.<br /><br />Lord might have some detail inaccuracies (e.g. specific aspects of being an arms dealer or the function of Interpol), but it makes up for it in being dead on accurate when it comes to focusing like a laser on moral hypocrisy.  Republican president Dwight D. Eisenhower warned us fifty years ago that the military-industrial complex would threaten this country and our world.  While we've been sleeping this is exactly what has been happening.<br /><br />Lord of War takes this fact by focusing on a single man, Yuri, (played by Nicolas Cage) who is completely devoid of any moral concerns.  For example, in one scene a dictator - a potential buyer - uses one of Yuri's brand new weapons to kill a nearby dallying soldier.  Yuri screams in outrage and the dictator takes pause.  How does Yuri dare challenge his absolute power to do as he pleases?  Yuri then explains that he has now used the weapon and must now purchase it.  The dictator laughs and Yuri's character establishes his credibility to both the dictator and to us, the audience.  It's all about the product - the money - and ethical concerns are irrelevant.<br /><br />The last minute of the movie is an earth shattering statement about how the western world - those responsible for keeping peace and security in the world - are a central part of the problem of violence and war in this world.  Just like the excellent Three Kings, Lord of War is destined to be a classic satirical statement about our world.  While it might now have done well at the box office, it will surely be greatly admired years from now.<br /><br />In any other year Lord of War would be a moderately well made movie.  In this season of films over filled with CGI and characters we could care less about, it easily ranks as one the best of 2005.

B000002UJQ|5.0|As far as I can tell, MTV Supporter is a joke account created by a quite brilliant satirist (unfortunately the joke is at the expense of this masterwork's rating).  I really find it hard to believe that anyone would find the album to lack melodic hooks or verse-chorus structure (Paranoid Android and Fitter Happier are the only really off-the-wall tunes, and Android is amazingly memorable).  There are very few well-written negative reviews (kudos to Michael Scott for an excellent example of an eloquent one), and to be honest I'm not really in a place to deny that the music may be difficult to listen to.  I'm a huge electronic music fan, and in fact came at Radiohead from an electronic perspective and not a guitar-based or acoustic one.  What sounds like very traditional and beautiful music to me may be complete garbage to someone else. <br /> <br />That being said, I think that OK Computer is the best album ever created, simply because it is an amazing gateway into true appreciation of music.  Anyone who can enjoy the entirety of OK Computer (yes, including Fitter Happier ;)) is ready to explore more advanced music, but it's so accesible to Rock and Alternative audiences that it makes the transition easy.  Radiohead is really the dream of progressive music - appealing to the mainstream while maintaining absolute creative vision (which is sustained throughout the entire album).  I really think this is an amazing accomplishment, and it's what makes the record so special. <br /> <br />I would like to respond to a couple specific issues.  The first is with the lyrics.  I must admit, these are not typical Pop or Rock lyrics, nor are they easy to understand (in terms of meaning and wading through Yorke's accent and singing style).  However, it's a lot of fun to figure out where exactly the chicken voices are coming from, and what constitutes a Gucci little piggy.  Ultimately, the lyrics are a lot more like poetry than prose, which is just something we're not used to hearing in popular music.  They shouldn't discourage anyone, and they're really great fun to sing along to once you figure them out (if you can match Thom's range, which I can't).  It's interesting to read the band's commentary on the words and music, if you can find it ([...] is a great resource), and their insight might make it more meaningful to you.  To potential buyers - this is a very deep and insightful album!  Don't let the words scare you, the music is more important anyway. <br /> <br />Someone else had an issue with the sound of the cymbals, so I would like to address the production of the album.  Nigel Godrich is more or less a musical genius, literally.  He was in his 20's when he produced this album, and it certainly does NOT sound like it was produced in 1997.  The cymbals are a bit unusual, there's a lot of high-end and reverb, and they sound a bit harsh (similar effect on the \\"I lost myself\\" on Karma Police).  Yeah, it's harsh.  I don't like it, to be honest.  I don't think it's a glaring flaw, and not really noticable on low volumes and certain speakers.  It does sound really interesting, and maybe someday I'll learn to appreciate it as a drummer.  I sincerely doubt it's going to detract from anyone's listening experience, however.  The rest of the album is AMAZINGLY produced, tunes like Let Down and Karma Police are truly, truly beautiful, and Homesick Alien and The Tourist are totally otherworldly.  It's an completely unique and magical sound that like many have said was completely ahead of its time. <br /> <br />I'll wrap up now, since that ended up being about four times as long as I intended.  I wanted to put forth the theory that MTV Supporter was joking so people don't waste any time responding to him, and I had to defend some of the other things people attacked about the album, since I really and truly believe it's a masterful record.  I can't recommend it to everyone, but anyone who appreciates progressive, alternative, or even semi-traditionalRock should pick this up, as well as any fan of electronic music.  I suggest everyone else give it a try - if you don't like it, it will make a nice gift to a friend or relative who for some reason or another doesn't have it yet. <br /> <br />Look at me, I registered an account at Amazon to write a novel about a record.  Hope it was helpful to someone. :) <br /> <br />Enjoy, <br />-Troupe
0156027321|2.0|I had heard many great reviews of this book. \\"A book that will make you believe in God\\" -- now that's ambitious. A lot of pressure to put on 319 pieces of paper...too much pressure, it turns out. The hype behind this book falls way short of expectations and just doesn't deliver. I'm not one to read books on religion or spirituality, so I was skeptical from the get-go. I put this book down after 60 or so pages the first time I tried it. I only picked it up the second time because it was a book club selection. I enjoyed the introduction and the last 30 pages or so. The pages in between were extremely slow, often disgusting, and just painstakingly uninteresting to me. I didn't care about the habits of wild animals nor the beliefs or Hindus, Christians and Muslims (at least not in reading-for-pleasure). I was just bored. In the end, I am glad I stuck it out, but still can't say I really liked this novel too much. I know that the symbolism and deeper meaning of this novel is what is supposed to stay with you, and the slow passage of time (through the Pacific and through the lines of the book) are supposed to deliver you, in a way, to a rebirth of sorts in the end. I liked the way it came together, the questions it raised, and I think that maybe after discussing it with friends, I may find I got something out of it. The novel asks, \\"Which is the better story?\\" Unfortunately, I don't think Martel would like my answer. Oh well.
B00009Z576|3.0|I recall plucking this 1980 album out of a cut-out bin in 1981 upon the recommendation of a friend, and was instantly taken with the brooding Roger Dean landscape that sprawled across the cover.  Once I got home and the needle hit the vinyl I was mesmerized - the wall of sound ushered in with Steve Howes opening (semi-heavy metal) guitar part on the thunderous Machine Messiah is something that I will never forget.<br /><br />Remarkably, after the passage of over 25 years the music on Drama still sounds pretty darn good to me and certainly represents drummer Alan White and bassist Chris Squire at their tightest (although they were fairly tight on Tormato too).  At 10'27\\" Machine Messiah is the proggiest piece on the album with Tempus Fugit being the most explosive - Squire simply rips on this piece.  Come to think of it, Squire pretty much rips up and down and sideways on this album.  The absence of Jon Anderson on Drama is somewhat depressing I guess, but then this album was about transitioning into a new decade and the decision to go with the Buggles pop duo of keyboardist Geoff Downes and vocalist Trevor Horn was obviously deliberate.  In fact, Yes adopted a very heavy sound on this album, which may have represented an attempt to adopt the stylistic attributes of the (then) massively popular \\"stadium rock\\" bands like Boston or Journey.  Although I found this unthinkable back then (and even today), Squire allowed Trevor Horn to play bass on Run Through the Light, which signified a further move to make Yes sound less \\"Yessy\\".  I would eventually go on to explore definitive works like Close to the Edge (1972) and Relayer (1974), but never liked any album released by Yes following Drama.<br /><br />All in all, the Rhino remastering job is excellent, although I really could have done without the additional ten bonus tracks, which contain pieces taken from the wretched \\"Paris Sessions\\" along with various outtakes from the Drama sessions.  The liner notes are nicely detailed and there are photos of the band scattered throughout.e are photos of the band scattered throughout.

6305907145|4.0|Unlike, say, 95% of the reviewers for this movie, I haven't read the book, and maybe that's why I'm giving it such high marks. <br /> <br />In the beginning of the movie, we meet Fanny who's the eldest daughter of an impoverished family (though the mother came from a middle class one) and she is being sent to live with her relatives. While she is kindly welcomed by the family, it's pretty clear that the differences in their social classes will always be evident, especially when it comes to her female cousins. <br /> <br />We later meet Edmund, her cousin and, in true 19th century British fashion, her love interest. Rather quickly, we're brought about ten years into the future where Fanny is around 20 years old and madly (though quietly) in love with Edmund and hopes that he'll realize he loves her, too. <br /> <br />With the entry of a well-to-do Henry and his sister, the comedy of errors is near complete. Henry is a playboy who, as Fanny realizes, craves attention and being loved. However much he flirts with her and her two cousins, she's still steadfast in her devotion to Edmund and refuses Henry's mulitiple offers of marriage--even when he follows her home from the Bertram's house to her family's dilapidated home on the docks. <br /> <br />While I'm somewhat familiar with other Austen works, it's clear that this movie has been shored up by vaguely modern characters, with modern viewpoints. In fact, I do find Fanny a bit more fiesty and steel-backed than is Austen's usual wont, but her moral fiber remains intact...even if the film's moral integrity seems a bit lacking. <br /> <br />The film blatantly points out the Bertram family's connection to the slave trade and we, quite shockingly, witness a nude scene (tame by modern standards) that Fanny takes quite well considering her gender and her time period. <br /> <br />Yet, despite the modern nuances evident in all aspects of the film, it's charm and Austen's wit are not to be overlooked. I like that there is dirt and grit in this film, unlike other squeaky-clean versions that would have us think this time period was nothing more than lilies and violet water. <br /> <br />The acting is solid and three-dimensional, the costuming and set design are authentic without being pretentious. <br /> <br />The only gripe that I have is that the romance between Edmund and Fanny is somewhat dull, though I have to admit, I find this in most adaptations of Austen's work (\\"Sense and Sensibility\\" excluded). There's no spark between the two, in fact, the younger Edmund who meets Fanny as a child is more enthralling than the elder. <br /> <br />But still, Austen is read and loved for her witty intelligence as much as for the romance, so the film delivered in at least one aspect. Overall, it was an entertaining movie that I highly enjoyed, then again, I haven't read the book.

B00001OH7P|5.0|'The Rise And Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars' was my introduction to David Bowie. It is a delicious, shimmering slice of pop perfection. The album is loosely based around the character of Ziggy Stardust, a rock n' rolling bisexual alien. However, contrary to popular belief, Ziggy was not intended to be a concept album at all! Songs such as 'Soul Love' and 'Suffragette City' as well as the last minute outtakes 'Round and Round' and 'Velvet Goldmine' do not enter into the story at all.  <br /> <br />The anthemic 'Five Years' is one of my all time favourite album openers. The lyrics are especially worth savouring, particularily when your brain feels like a warehouse and you're drinking milkshakes cold and long. Having only five years left to live has never been this much fun. The gourgeously melodic 'Soul Love' paves the way for Ziggy's grand entrance in 'Moonage Daydream.' Part \\"space invader\\", part \\"rock n' rolling bitch\\", Ziggy wreaks havoc amongst Mick Ronson's swirling guitar solo. The first single 'Starman' borrows the melody from Over the Rainbow and basically blows our minds. Bowie's cover version of 'It Ain't Easy' and 'Lady Stardust', an ode to Marc Bolan round out the middle of the album. The second half of the album is more kinetic and frantically paced than the first. Ziggy declares his ambition to become a \\"rock and roll star\\" and delights in his growing fame in 'Star' and 'Hang on To Yourself.' Another anthem, 'Ziggy Stardust' describes the tragic downfall of Ziggy at the hand of his jealous bandmembers the Spiders from Mars. After ripping through the all out rocker 'Suffragette City', 'Rock N' Roll Suicide' sadly laments Ziggy's death.  <br /> <br />This was my first Bowie album and will always hold a very special place in my heart. Some regard this as his finest album. Although I think this is a brilliant piece of work, in my opinion Bowie had yet to reach greater heights. Nevertheless, very highly recommended and a magical introduction to an amazing artist.
0553804367|5.0|I read the earlier book, \\"A Brief History of Time\\" by Hawking and this book delivers where it states, in updating where things have advanced as well as putting the cookies on the lower shelf by writing conversationally and without the use of academic verbiage and mathmatical equations that would be lost on the general audience it targets.<br /><br />What criticisms can no doubt be leveled for it's simplicity, are somewhat specious because its simplicity is the point.<br /><br />The explanations offered for the creation of stars, black holes, white holes, dark energy, dark matter, parrallel dimensions and universes and the possibility of time travel are fascinating and very enlightening.  Science indeed has come a long way in a relatively (pun intented) brief (second pun also intended) period of time.<br /><br />I applaud Hawking and those in his field with their progress and discoveries.  They are indeed exciting.<br /><br />I don't tend to put the same amount of faith into Stephen Hawking's belief that Physics is on the verge of coming up with a \\"Grand Unified Theory\\" that explains every element of the beginnings, development and sustenance of the universe.  I tend to believe that as more answers are found, there will be new questions raised and that we may well find ourselves in the paradox of the finite seeking to comprehend and grasp the infinite.  In that regard, I find Hawking's goals and beliefs, while laudable, somewhat unrealistic.  That is not unexpected because what Hawking is doing here is pushing right up on the border of Physics with Metaphysics.  Science can answer \\"what\\" and \\"how,\\" but it will forever be limited to answer \\"why\\".<br /><br />A prime example of this is when Hawking in effect dabbles in the realm of predestination speculating as to the possibility of all biological action, development and even thought as explainable should formulas be determined for the random possibilities.  Interesting.  Welcome to the realm of Reformed Theology approached through a different venue but with the same mysteries for which there is no apparent satisfying answer, Mr Hawking!  ;)<br /><br />I do not doubt or discount the need to continue the attempt to reduce the universe to complete scientific equation and understanding. I came away from this book excited at the progress, curious as to future developments and very much better for the time and effort expended.<br /><br />This is a keeper and I will reread it.  Great book!the same mysteries for which there is no apparent satisfying answer, Mr Hawking!  ;)    I do not doubt or discount the need to continue the attempt to reduce the universe to complete scientific equation and understanding. I came away from this book excited at the progress, curious as to future developments and very much better for the time and effort expended.    This is a keeper and I will reread it.  Great book!

B0002Z0EYK|4.0|I read Lawrence Bernabo's prominate review. I agree with most of his assertions regarding many aspects of the film, especially killing off people who were supposed to survive, like Menelaos for one. He was to return and rule with his contrite wife Helen. Who would Telemachos, from the Odyssey, visit when in search of his father ten years later? I highly disagree with the idea of leaving out the GODS--it was so clearly a part of what motivated, protected and tricked the heroes. Their presence would have explained so much. Without Aphrodite, how does Paris get out of the battle with Menelaos? The mystical element would have deepended the storyline and intensified many scenes. Why butcher Homer so badly? Can you imagine what it would have been like to see Athena whip Achilles's (Brad Pitt's) head back warning him about using his anger to murder Agamemnon? And if Paris is such a whimp, it would only make sense that Helen would follow him because Aphrodite had assisted him. It also would have added a much needed layer to Paris's character. He had been a shepard for most of his life, not a prince. No matter how many times Peterson goes back to rework his movie--he can't undo the story damage. Yes, the battle scenes are great, Achilles is certainly well cast in Brad Pitt--remember he was supposed to be pretty enough to pass for a girl. And that they made his most treasured friend his cousin? Are we so uptight that we can't show affection and bonds between men who fight and train together? The love that ripped Achilles heart out was the loss of Patroklos. It was the final piece in the unraveling of Achilles's character. The \\"cousin\\" element was never what Homer had envisioned. When a director takes THIS much license with a major story, it makes it impossible to tell the second part through film without people scratching their heads.<br /><br />I do agree that the less you know about the actual story, the more you will most likely enjoy it. B000001EXR|4.0|Prior to the reunion of the original line-up and seemingly endless tour that followed, KISS decided to show they could be as contemporary as the grungers of the period (1995).  What could have been a cheap derivative in other bands' hands became the heaviest album KISS ever delivered, the Seattle influence present but not dominating. I have no problem believing KISS could do whatever they set their minds to, judged by the evidence on this platter.
B000AWYOGE|4.0|Dark Water<br /><br />Suffering through a bitter custody battle, Dahlia (Jennifer Connelly) and her daughter Ceci (Ariel Gade) have moved into a rundown New York City apartment to start a new life. The place, run by an eccentric manager (a scene-stealing John C. Reilly), and an even stranger superintendent (Pete Postlethwaite), isn't very welcoming, but Dahlia decides to give it her best shot. Mysterious occurrences start arriving with the appearance of a leaky ceiling in the apartment that drips black water. The water soon starts to appear everywhere to Dahlia, leading her to the brink of sanity. She tries to hold it together for Ceci, but the young girl is also dealing with the haunted surroundings, and the sinister nature of her new imaginary friend.<br /><br />Just glancing at \\"Dark Water\\" you can feel a wince coming on. The latest entry in the Japanese horror remake fiesta, \\"Water\\" comes to American shores with an ace up its sleeve: filmmaker Walter Salles. Directly off his international sensation, \\"The Motorcycle Diaries,\\" the Brazilian director comes to this remake of the 2002 horror hit with some bright ideas on mood and suspense. After watching \\"The Ring\\" and \\"The Grudge\\" (along with some other knock-offs) go horribly wrong, it's a small treat to see \\"Dark Water\\" translate so well to these shores.<br /><br />We've seen it before: ghost kids, spooky corners, imposing faucets. \\"Dark Water\\" doesn't feature too many firsts in its plot. Salles steps up to this challenge by forcing the material to bend to his will, creating a sensational mood of emotional destruction, baked with a crust of paranoia. \\"Water\\" isn't necessarily a \\"boo!\\" experience like the marketing suggests; Salles is much more interested in detailing the emotional seam bursting that is consuming Dahlia, and her decent into madness and guilt. No actress in the world is better suited for this gloomy journey than Jennifer Connelly, who is pitch-perfect in her role here. Salles smothers the film in darkness and moisture, weaving a mysterious, suspenseful vibe. Connelly is right there to back him up at every turn, providing a strong human core to the fantastical surroundings, and brilliantly matching the dark tone Salles is methodically arranging.<br /><br />\\"Water\\" eventually succumbs to the obvious when ghost children start running around and the scare factor is turned up. Salles himself doesn't appear too interested in giving his audience the willies, but he does score an awesome climax, which is both unexpected and astonishing, considering this project comes from Disney. I can forgive some rather inane leaps at spooks when the ending is this good.<br /><br />Salles is even able to make his film compelling after original director Hideo Nakata stole most of the ideas for his \\"Ring Two\\" sequel from earlier this year. \\"Water\\" and \\"Two\\" have so much in common, I'm shocked lawsuits weren't filed. At the end of the day, Salles is just so much more interesting a filmmaker than Nakata, and he finds magic by making d&eacute;j&agrave; vu seem brand spanking new.<br /><br />\\"Dark Water\\" is familiar material twisted into interesting directions, and even if it doesn't always succeed dramatically, the attempt is clear, and I appreciate the film for that alone. I hope Salles takes more dips in the Hollywood pool in the future.m in darkness and moisture, weaving a mysterious, suspenseful vibe. B000BBOUU4|4.0|Charlie and the Chocolate Factory<br /><br />Willy Wonka's (Johnny Depp) plan to spruce up his chocolate business is to plant five golden tickets randomly in his Wonka bars inviting the holders to a tour of his factory. For poor Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore, \\"Finding Neverland\\"), chances for a ticket are slim, but luck is on his side; joining spoiled Veruca Salt (Julia Winter), competitive Violent Beauregard (Annasophia Robb), perpetually consuming Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz), and violent Mike Teavee (Jordon Fry), Charlie meets Wonka, the reclusive, eccentric fellow behind the delights of his factory. As the tour commences, weird things start happening to the selfish, misbehaving children, leaving Charlie alone to deal with Wonka's bizarre behavior, and to try to help him out.<br /><br />If not exactly a classic film, Mel Stuart's 1971 fantasy creation, \\"Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory\\" has stood the test of time with its tender realization of childhood sugar fantasies and morbid, goofball humor. With Gene Wilder at the helm of the considerable steerage of oddities, this loose Roald Dahl adaptation has aged as a major 1970s peculiarity, yet, at the same time, remained wonderful. Over 30 years later, noted quirkmeister Tim Burton has taken up the challenge to bring the book (with the true \\"Charlie\\" title) to the screen again, and he's out to reclaim the cinema version for himself.<br /><br />Immediately, comparing the two productions becomes a fruitless quest. The Stuart film was made in an era of musicals, practical effects, and gee-whiz kid acting. Burton's film exists in a more cynical time, with a more sarcastic filmmaker. Opening with Danny Elfman's familiar scoring backing the creation, by cold steel machines, of the Wonka bars, the tone is clearly set: this is no candy shop, and the candy man can't. Burton has more in store for his audience than simple sweets and soft-shoe.<br /><br />With a rapturous and meticulous production design, a tongue firmly placed in cheek, and the appearance of Christopher Lee as Willy's dentist dad, this is a Burton film through and through. That being established, \\"Charlie\\" is a chilly affair, more concerned with technical prowess than heart or plot. For the most part, this change in focus is fine, for Burton's take on Willy's chocolate factory is a marvel, packed with infinite candy rooms, singing, dancing, cocoa-bean worshiping Oompa Loompas (all played by movie MVP, Deep Roy, \\"The Neverending Story\\"), and legitimate danger. While a lot of the film is sweetened with CGI, Burton still palms the primal magic of Wonka's wonderland with his extensive visuals, and the depth and life he gives the factory is almost perfect.<br /><br />Almost perfect can also be said of Johnny Depp, who steps out of the mile-long shadow of Gene Wilder to fashion his own twisted take on Willy. Since the aim for \\"Charlie\\" isn't pointed at the heart, Depp's Wonka is a strange fellow who hates parents, is easily annoyed by children, and appears to be a germaphobe. Not exactly the winking teddy bear Wilder went after in his legendary performance, but Depp's oddball acting fits heavenly with Burton's vision, and the two team up yet again for another rousing, wildly original collaboration.<br /><br />However, with Depp and the computer effects taking the lead, poor little Charlie isn't left with much to do. Freddie Highmore is an inspired choice for the unlikely Golden Ticket winner, and his English puppy dog demeanor does the film a world of good in the emotion department. But Burton keeps Charlie at arm's length for the entire film, along with the other kid actors (who aren't nearly as interesting or natural as Highmore), leaving unfair comparisons to the stellar child acting work in the original incarnation to dance through the head.<br /><br />Tim Burton's \\"Charlie\\" corrects many mistakes from the Stuart film (the Oompas aren't creepily orange and green anymore, and Burton has mercifully done away withthe infamously bizarre, psychedelic boat trip sequence), along with raising the epic visual stakes for the more visionary angles of the story that needed it. Burton has created a genuinely fun movie for the family, blessed with a zippy running time, and those tired of the Wilder warmth for this often ominous tale will rejoice over this new icy stab at detailing Wonka's outrageous tour.ully done away with the infamously bizarre, psychedelic boat trip sequence), along with raising the epic visual stakes for the more visionary angles of the story that needed it. Burton has created a genuinely fun movie for the family, blessed with a zippy running time, and those tired of the Wilder warmth for this often ominous tale will rejoice over this new icy stab at detailing Wonka's outrageous tour.

B000BKVQTS|3.0|Terry Gilliam, the only American member of the Monty Python troupe, and director of such quirky classics as \\"Brazil,\\" \\"Time Bandits,\\" \\"The Fisher King,\\" \\"Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,\\" \\"The Adventures Of Baron Munchausen\\" and \\"Monty Python & The Holy Grail,\\" among others, does it again with bizarre combination of Munchausen and Tim Burton's \\"Sleepy Hollow,\\" with a little bit of \\"The Village\\" thrown in.<br /><br />This dark-humored film relates the completely-fictional story of the famous German brothers, Wilhelm (Matt Damon) and Jakob (Heath Ledger) Grimm, who created dozens of fairy tales and nursery stories for children in the early 19th Century. True to Gillian's idiosyncratic style, though, the movie plays nothing straight down the line. In this case, the brothers are con artists, traveling through the French-occupied German villages (remember Napoleon was big in those days) and playing on the fears and superstitions of their idiot occupants.<br /><br />Wearing goofy armor, shouting made-up incantations, and using hidden assistants, sleight of hand and other trickery, they fool these hicks into paying them big money, that is until they are finally captured by French forces, and sent to a town where several young girls have gone missing. The two arrive with little fanfare, as well as several French soldiers and Cavaldi (Peter Stormare, \\"Birth,\\" \\"Bad Boys 2\\"), the evil Italian inquisitor of Gen. Delatombe (Jonathan Pryce, \\"Brazil\\") to try and solve the mystery. If they fail, they will be tortured and executed.<br /><br />Since, of course, they are fakes, they have no idea what they're doing but, with the assistance of a female trapper, they discover a crumbling tower deep within a foreboding forest. The woman remembers her father telling her the story of an evil queen who sealed herself up there to avoid a plague that was killing her subjects. It seems this tower and whatever now lives inside of it may be the cause of all the trouble.<br /><br />Borrowing heavily from \\"Sleepy Hollow,\\" the two have gadgets and inventions which were far ahead of their time (and thus completely illogical to those around them). Their efforts to solve the disappearances are clumsy and awkward, but somehow they stumble onto clue after clue. All the while they exchange silly and witty bon mots while trying to outsmart the bad guys and themselves. Even better performances come from Pryce and especially Cavaldi, who is evil, smarmy and pathetic.<br /><br />Always a stickler for historic details, Gilliam's costumes and set design are perfect for 1804 Europe (the film was shot in Prague), when Napoleon was at the peak of his powers and the continent was pretty much under French control.<br /><br />Weaved throughout the film are any number of the Grimm fables, including \\"Cinderella,\\" \\"Sleeping Beauty,\\" \\"Rapunzel,\\" \\"The Frog Prince,\\" \\"Little Red Riding Hood,\\" \\"Hansel And Gretel\\" and \\"The Gingerbread Man,\\" among others, while the iconoclastic Gilliam throws in subtle and not-too-subtle jokes, dialogue and situations.<br /><br />Here, many who may not understand or appreciate the director's roots, may turn away and condemn the project, misinterpreting Gilliam's often-frantic camera-work and reliance on special effects as a metaphor for his lack of vision or ingenuity. Nothing could be further from the truth. \\"Grimm,\\" while certainly not up to the standards set in some of his earlier work, is nonetheless an interesting, creative and visually-intriguing film. Yes, it does tend to bog down every now and then, while the violent comedy, at times, is a bit forced, but, overall, that detracts little from the entire film.g heavily from \\"Sleepy Hollow,\\" the two have gadgets and inventions which were far ahead of their time (and thus completely illogical to those around them). Nothing could be further from the truth. \\"Grimm,\\" while certainly not up to the standards set in some of his earlier work, is nonetheless an interesting, creative and visually-intriguing film. 0553801503|1.0|All I can say is, I'm glad that, unlike so many frustrated Martin fans, I didn't wait five years for this book to emerge.  I started this series a couple of years ago - after I abandoned Robert Jordan's 'Wheel of Time' for the same reason I will now abandon Martin -  failing to satisfy his readers. <br /> <br />The author has now joined the ranks of the 'kitchen sink' school of writing.  While abandoning the important characters that we had grown to love (or hate) he elects to throw in so many new - and unnecessary - faces that it all dissolves into a meaningless clutter.  Nothing will jolt a reader out of a story worse than having to constantly refer to an appendix to try to keep track of 'who's who' - which I did several times before I finally decided that the plot wasn't worth the effort.  Martin writes page after page of meaningless drivel, while failing to resolve any of the issues that readers wanted resolved.   <br /> <br />I had taken the title 'A Feast for Crows' to mean that the epic battle for the Iron Throne would be fought in this book, leaving the vanquished lying on the battlefield - 'a feast for crows'.  I'm sure the author knew this as well, but I wonder if he knew how many readers were going to be so thoroughly dissatisfied with what emerged.  Martin has written a very boring book and neglected the really signifcant characters from his previous works (those that he hadn't already killed off).  I doubt the promised sequel will be any better.   <br /> <br />I feel intellectually (as well as financially) cheated by Martin's latest offering and he has lost me as a fan. For those who insist on sticking with this never-ending saga, I say, don't waste your money on this one.  Any synopsis on the net will suffice.  Sad to see, but Martin has joined the ranks of those who choose to keep a story going long after it should have been concluded, simply for the cash flow, with no regard for the reader's desires.  I have had enough. <br /> <br />Dr. F. Batton

Chris Nolan and the others responsible for the film obviously had done their homework. Taking the best from Batman comics (more than just the look-but the story) and making one MOTHER of a great movie out of them. (Most notably they borrowed a great deal from Frank Miller's \\"Batman Year One\\" which is one of the greatest Batman comics I've ever read.)  <br /> <br />After Joel \\"I'm of the opinion that more florescent lights and awful casting will make Batman movies better\\" Schumacher, Chris Nolan has actually renewed my faith that Batman films could be good again so much that I eagerly anticipate their sequels. This film is so good that even my wife, who is not a comic or Batman fan, likes it very much. It is great! Great story, great characters, great action, great look and feel, and great casting and acting. If you are thinking about buying this movie, buy it now. You will not be disappointed.  <br /> <br />Caesar says two thumbs way up! <br />
B00005JO04|4.0|****1/2<br /><br />How can a movie be THIS compelling and engrossing, yet still be so difficult to follow?  That is the question I found myself asking all the way through \\"Syriana,\\" a fascinating political thriller that keeps you riveted to your seat for well over two hours yet is almost completely incomprehensible for most of that running time.  The mark of a great filmmaker usually lies in how well he is able to illuminate a complex subject for a less-than-enlightened or essentially uninformed audience.  In this case, however, writer/director Stephen Gaghan's refusal - or is it inability? - to unravel the entanglements in his narrative somehow works in the movie's favor.  Is it because the subject matter itself is so messy and incoherent that the presentation of it needs to be as well?  Whatever the case, \\"Syriana\\" is a wholly riveting and absorbing cinematic experience - even if only a tiny percentage of it makes any real sense.  (And don't forget that coherence of plot, in and of itself, is not necessarily a prerequisite for a quality film.  After all, it`s widely admitted that the screenplay for \\"The Big Sleep\\" is virtually impossible to figure out, yet that film is considered a classic).<br /><br />Based on the book by Robert Baer, Gaghan's tale takes us to the dark heart of international oil politics, where strategies are planned and deals are struck, often at the expense of individual freedoms and the snuffing out of thousands of innocent lives.  Gaghan shows us the behind-the-scenes wheeling and dealing, power politics, corporate corruption, governmental malfeasance, human exploitation and personal betrayals that go into filling up the gas tanks of our SUVs.  In this turbulent Middle Eastern world of sectarian strife, arms deals and acts of terror, Gaghan finds little room for good guys or heroes, although he does imply that heroic ACTS may indeed be possible.  Instead, he shows how all of us, to some degree or another, share in this shame.<br /><br />Rather than taking a purely linear approach in his narrative (which would certainly have made things more understandable) , Gaghan, as he did in \\"Traffic,\\" provides us with an assortment of characters and storylines that often seem arbitrary and disconnected from one another.  This is primarily why the confusion arises, for we are often whisked from one subplot to another before the first has been fully explicated.  The film is something like a mosaic; it doesn't really matter if every single detail doesn't attain complete clarity as long as we are able to pull back and focus our eyes on the big picture Gaghan shows us.<br /><br />There's not much point in trying to relate the fine points of the complex plot here.  Suffice it to say that the film is filled with vivid scenes and memorable moments, as well as outstanding performances by George Clooney, Matt Damon, Christopher Plummer, Chris Cooper, Amanda Peet, Kayvan Novak, Amr Waked and many others.<br /><br />By plunging headlong into the most timely and important issue of our time - the violent clash between Western secularism and Muslim extremism - \\"Syriana\\" certainly establishes itself as one of the bravest and best movies of 2005.  However, it may take a few additional viewings on the part of the head-scratchers to convince THEM of that./> <br />Rather than taking a purely linear approach in his narrative (which would certainly have made things more understandable) , Gaghan, as he did in \\"Traffic,\\" provides us with an assortment of characters and storylines that often seem arbitrary and disconnected from one another.  This is primarily why the confusion arises, for we are often whisked from one subplot to another before the first has been fully explicated.  The film is something like a mosaic; it doesn't really matter if every single detail doesn't attain complete clarity as long as we are able to pull back and focus our eyes on the big picture Gaghan shows us.   <br /> <br />There's not much point in trying to relate the fine points of the complex plot here.  Suffice it to say that the film is filled with vivid scenes and memorable moments, as well as outstanding performances by George Clooney, Matt Damon, Christopher Plummer, Chris Cooper, Amanda Peet, Kayvan Novak, Amr Waked and many others.  <br /> <br />By plunging headlong into the most timely and important issue of our time - the violent clash between Western secularism and Muslim extremism - \\"Syriana\\" certainly establishes itself as one of the bravest and best movies of 2005.  However, it may take a few additional viewings on the part of the head-scratchers to convince THEM of that.
B00006L83N|5.0|'The Odyssey' is possibly the greatest Symphony X album ever released.  I've been following the band ever since I heard \\"Out of the Ashes\\" from the 'Divine Wings' album, and I've gotten every album since then.  I appreciated the experimental side to 'V', but I felt it focused too much on symphonic overtones.  Was this the new direction that Symphony X was going for?  I had thought so, and while I was perfectly capable of accepting a symphonic edge to the band, I was a guitar freak at heart.  Then came 'The Odyssey'; featuring a perfect blend of wall-to-wall guitar and keyboards, this release showcased the melodic and technical capabilities of the band while not completely doing away with the symphonic overtones featured on 'V'.  I had the pleasure of talking to Michael Lepond (bassist) after it was released, and although he was a bit disappointed with the level of his bass in the mix - and I'll admit, it's a little low, but not as bad as Metallica's  '...And Justice For All' - he was proud of the product.  I took his opinion seriously, but I wanted to hear for myself.  When it came out in stores, I (regretfully) went for the non-limited edition.  Looking back, I should have waited for the special edition to be stocked, because it includes one extra song, but I wanted to hear the material right away.<br /><br />So I bought the album and fed it into the CD player.  Out blasted a frenetic sequence of guitar notes, the intro of \\"Inferno\\", to set the stage of the album.  While I would hardly call \\"Inferno\\" my favorite song on the disk, it did leave an impact.  Then I hit \\"Wicked\\", an awesome, slow-driving song which remains at the top of my Symphony X song list ever since hearing it; Russell Allen's vocal work shines on that song.  Whoever calls \\"Awakenings\\" a weak ballad must be ignorant (in my opinion).  The song starts off with a syncopated introduction between the bass, drums, and keyboards, and goes through a transformation as distorted guitars are added in; very symphonic and pleasant sounding.<br /><br />Then I reached the title track, a 24-minute long epic called \\"The Odyssey\\".  Split into seven parts, the song begins with an orchestrated session (accentuated with some heavy guitars and drums) that sounds like it came right out of a movie.  Around the four minute mark, Michael Romeo sets his guitar on clean and brings the song into a peaceful-sounding interlude with Russell Allen.  Later in the song, you'll hear an answer to that same part, but not before encountering heavy guitars at the 6-minute mark, vocal-layering and pulsating keyboards at the 13-minute mark, a bumbling guitar stampede at the 15-minute mark, and another orchestrated session at the 17.  Despite the diversity mentioned here, the song flows very well for the most part, and it could very well make the album deserving of five stars in itself if it were offered as a single.<br /><br />Overall, I believe this is Symphony X's most solid attempt.  Offering a great blend of symphony and guitar, I gave this album the highest rating available.  Great album; truly a must-have.symphonic and pleasant sounding. <br /> <br />Then I reached the title track, a 24-minute long epic called \\"The Odyssey\\". Offering a great blend of symphony and guitar, I gave this album the highest rating available.  Great album; truly a must-have.
B000002UA2|5.0|What's most amazing about this album is they wrote and recorded it in a couple of weeks. This tight sounding soundtrack album is the most underrated of all of pink floyds output. For guitar fans, this album contains some of David Gilmours best pre-dark side of the moon guitar solos. Free Four, the song that, as far as I'm concerned, set Roger Waters Lyrical direction for the next decade, could have and should have been a pink floyd pop hit. This album should be owned by any real pink floyd fan because this was the pink floyd album that didn't worry about concepts and just let the music do the talking. So pop this in the CD player, sit back, crack open a cold one, and enjoy.  <br />P.S. How can you just own Dark Side of the Moon without wanting to buy the whole set? B000024D4R|5.0|Admittedly, it took me a while to get into this album. I listened to it, after I bought it, expecting another listener friendly album the likes of DSOTM or the Wall, and found this one to be rather tedious to begin with. In fact, I was downright intimidated, buy the 17 minute Magna Opus \\"Dogs\\", and skipped to the next song 5 minutes into it. That was then, though, and this is now. About five years after purchasing Animals I listened to Roger Waters Version of \\"Dogs\\" on his \\"In the Flesh\\" live album, having nearly forgotten all about the orignal album, as it got very little play on my stereo. For some reason, from that moment on I was hooked. I guess what I'm saying is give this some time, if it doesn't appeal to you on your first listen, because this album will pay huge dividends to your ears and mind in the years to come.<br /><br />\\"Pigs on the Wing\\" is a nice little introduction, but in my book it's more or less fluff around the meat of the album which starts with \\"Dogs\\". From the opening acoustic guitar to the final \\"dragged down by the stone,\\" I can't get enough of this song anymore, and often times wish it was longer, maybe 26 minutes like echos. On the other hand, when I'm listening to the first 4 or 5 minutes, I often wonder why they didn't cut a 5 or 6 minute radio friendly friendly version of it, as well, to release as a single. A searing commentary, this song is, on, you know who you are, the Gordon Geckos of the world.<br /><br />\\"Pigs, three different ones,\\" is also a great song, but somehow pales in comparison to dogs. The only mistake they made on this album was putting \\"Dogs\\" at the beginning, because if they'd have put \\"sheep\\" first followed by \\"pigs\\", then \\"dogs,\\" a person could have enjoyed the first two songs more with \\"Dogs\\" as the inevitable finally. As it is, as good as Pigs and Sheep sound, by themselves, I'm always wanting for more when they follow Dogs. Other then the fact this may have screwed up Roger's concept, musically it would have made a lot more sense.<br /><br />But I'm splitting hairs now. Bottom line, this has evolved into my favorite Floyd album, and for a fanatical fan like myself, that's saying a lot. If you own DSOTM, WYWH and the Wall, there is no reason not to complete the set of albums which made the Floyd the rock gods they've become.

0393327655|5.0|One of the most brilliant and important books I have read in a nearly 60-year lifetime of reading.  Harris unflinchingly asks the questions that too few are willing to confront --i.e., why would any concious human being allow him or herself and the children they raise to be so massively influenced by one or another of the principal religious belief systems that are all at their core inherently divisive, exclusionary, and -- worst of all --well proven to inspire acts of astounding violence against others of different faiths.  Why can't we all come together around such basic universal norms as the Golden Rule that should work for secular as well as faith-based believers?  In terrifying and exhaustive detail, Harris's revealing examination of Islamic texts leaves not one scintilla of doubt that for Islamic adherents peaceful co-existence with non-believers is virtually impossible to conceive.  This is not chicken-little 'the-sky-is-falling' demagoguery (as is often the case when political partisans run amok), but cooly rational, highly accessible prose at the highest level of erudition and not without plenty of entertaining wit and calm perspective.  Absolutely required reading for every thinking person.

B000AYEI5Y|5.0|i was reminded of the first time i heard elton john's first album upon listening to james blunt's sometimes haunting, heartfelt, and imaginative cd, 'back to bedlam'. the comparison is by no means an insult. but wait, this is elton with one part sigmund freud and 2 parts bob dylan thrown in for good measure...shaken and stirred...and what an important and timely poetic cocktail this mixture yields.  if this album offers a glimpse of what is to come, it's the start of a similar career path for james blunt. no, no...i'm not predicting sunglasses, histrionic narcissism, and ever-expanding waistlines...rather, a path rich in folky, free association style, & fantastically revealing music that projects both the vulnerability of the human existential condition and the importance of compassion and love born of meaningful connections (in a world where this is increasingly harder to achieve). there is a underlying tone of melancholy to blunt's lyrics and singing voice that i greatly appreciate. it's genuine.  blunt's songs tell of pain, regret and internal conflict (and those little converstions that we have within our heads).  we feel resignation and, all at once, rage against the machine (sometimes within the same passage). this is rare stuff indeed.  in an age of techno-babble and dizzying mixes and remixes, this is just what the good doctor ordered. we all need more authenticity in our lives. as one other reviewer stated, blunt's voice may take some getting used to, but the rewards will be many to the listener who gives this a fair shake. of final note, i appreciate the continuity of the songs. they all seem to reflect the same relevant themes through different stories and circumstances. it's one of the best albums of 2005, hands down...   5 stars.

B0000942QM|5.0|I've been hearing and seeing people elsewhere bicker about this imported remaster, so I'm going to clear up the facts and variations to this album, as it is in-comparable in similarity to the second original release which some heard back in 1985. <br /> <br />This re-release is neither the re-master of the USA, German, or original UK versions that were issued under ZZT publisher. It's actually the remaster of the \\"actual\\" original album published under ZZT/Polystar, and Island Records in the first quarters of 1985 (which was issued all over Japan and Germany). As some are saying tracks like \\"Dr. Mabuse\\" and \\"Jewell\\" are sounding more off beat and with ill-reverb. The second issue album which became the commercial release held up to 10-11 tracks. With \\"Dr. Mabuse\\" separated from \\"Strength To Dream.\\" In the original release they were together, and it was titled in composite \\"Das Testament Des Mabuse.\\" So before buying, here is the actual track list of what your getting other than what's printed or clarified on the label. <br /> <br />1. 9:08 Dream Within A Dream (extended and remixed) <br />2. 5:13 The Murder Of Love <br />3. 6:23 Jewel (cut rough minus the first cut intro) <br />4. 4:43 Duel (cd remix) <br />5. 4:25 Frozen Faces <br />6. 3:50 p:Machinery (single mix, which was on all releases) <br />7. 3:27 Sorry For Laughing <br />8. 4:05 The Chase <br />9. 10:42 Das Testament Des Mabuse/Strength To Dream [\\"Dr. Mabuse\\"] <br /> <br />DVD (Region 2) 5.1: Music Videos and Discography Gallery) <br />1 Dr. Mabuse (Version 1)  <br />2 Dr. Mabuse (Version 2)  <br />3 Duel (Version 1) <br />4 Duel (Version 2) <br />5 p-machinery  <br /> <br />Does it make it less worth the buck for importing? The sound is much better and crystal than it has ever been, and it comes with goodies if you have a region free DVD player on ya!

0385513755|5.0|Occasionally I pick some work of \\"popular fiction\\" that I think might be fun to read; it's shock therapy for my brain, which is so crammed with science that it rattles as I walk. I'd resisted reading The Da Vinci Code since 2003, thinking that any book this popular can't be any good. Can you say SNOB? But when I saw this Special Illustrated Edition (and the incessant drumbeat of publicity and shameless media linkage to the book, like the History Channel's \\"Da Vinci Decoded\\"), I finally broke-down and read it.<br /><br />Dan Brown's book is a taut page turner. It deals with several rather controversial assertions (to say the least) about Christianity. Whether you choose to believe them or not is a personal decision. Many are taken from another controversial book published in 1982, Holy Blood, Holy Grail. As Mr. Brown's book is a work of Fiction, I just went along for the ride and disregarded all the hoopla. As a thriller, it is one of the best I've ever read. It is intelligently written, with almost no excess material. Some of Mr. Brown's plot choices puzzled me; like the strange attack of \\"the dumbs\\" afflicting his 3 allegedly brilliant protagonists late in the book when they're unable to identify a very famous scientist from rather obvious clues. Or their inability to identify the food item associated with that scientist, something any school child knows. Crucial to the plot, obvious to the reader, their sudden obtuseness was the only real fault - if it is a fault - that I could find in this otherwise exciting novel.<br /><br />What really compounded my pleasure in reading this novel were the carefully chosen illustrations, generously interspersed throughout the Special Edition. Resembling an Oxford University Illustrated History in size and layout, reading the Special Edition was like reading a really exciting textbook (How rare is that?). Every fact came alive, every clue was vivid. It was a totally immersive experience, like a turn-based video game. And when we reached The Last Supper in the novel, visually flipping back and forth from text to painting was viscerally exciting! Those mysterious visual clues Da Vinci inserted into his magnificent painting are literally seared into my memory. I had gooseflesh for three days!<br /><br />The Special Illustrated Edition of the Da Vinci Code accomplished what I intended: my brain no longer rattles as I walk. Unfortunately, the book (and the fun) had to end. If you haven't yet read it, I strongly recommend this Special Edition. Even if you have, this experience is unique, unlike any reading adventure I've ever had. You might enjoy rediscovering the mysteries that make reading the Da Vinci Code so enjoyable!<br /><br />Postscript: As for those of you who wish to censor this book; who even censor positive reviews of this book (the instantaneous negative votes for every single positive review of The Da Vinci Code here at Amazon is as creepy as anything found in Dan Brown's Book!): censorship of ideas has never worked and never will! It reflects a strange feebleness of mind and an insecure, even frightened, faith! One can enjoy this novel without subscribing to the extraneous conspiracy theories the plot is draped upon. It is merely a work of fiction, for goodness sake! Apparently, however, anyone with a viewpoint that's even nominally different must be silenced. Now, where have we all seen that before?!<br /><br />Mike BirmanSupper in the novel, visually flipping back and forth from text to painting was viscerally exciting! Those mysterious visual clues Da Vinci inserted into his magnificent painting are literally seared into my memory. I had gooseflesh for three days!    The Special Illustrated Edition of the Da Vinci Code accomplished what I intended: my brain no longer rattles as I walk. Unfortunately, the book (and the fun) had to end. If you haven't yet read it, I strongly recommend this Special Edition. Even if you have, this experience is unique, unlike any reading adventure I've ever had. You might enjoy rediscovering the mysteries that make reading the Da Vinci Code so enjoyable! It reflects a strange feebleness of mind and an insecure, even frightened, faith! One can enjoy this novel without subscribing to the extraneous conspiracy theories the plot is draped upon. It is merely a work of fiction, for goodness sake! Apparently, however, anyone with a viewpoint that's even nominally different must be silenced. Now, where have we all seen that before?!    Mike Birman

0030839939|4.0|The 20th century saw the birth of quantum mechanics, and its connection with physics, chemistry and engineering to form the discipline collectively known as solid state science.  Dealing with the properties of solids at the atomic-scale, the advances in this field have made the entire Digital Age possible.  As such, the literature, both educational and scientific, in this field has grown exponentially over the past 50 years.  One of the best books in this field is Solid State Physics by Ashcroft and Mermin.  This extremely thorough book covers the field from basic crystallography and bonding models up through magnetic, optical, and superconducting properties.  The book includes lots of derivations, sample problems, and all the important equations.  Also, the book covers both experimental techniques used in solid state science, and the growing field of computer simulations, especially those using density functional theory.  All in all a great book to read for those working in or planning to work in this field.
B000002542|4.0|It took me a long time to get into the first three Journey albums, but they finally grew on me. This first one takes a little longer than the following two to get into, but still it's a solid release. There are some people who hate the poppy sound that Journey would make with Steve Perry, but can get into this completely, because it's totally light years removed from the Steve Perry fronted sachharin sweet pop group of the early to mid eighties. I like the Steve Perry phase also, but sometimes this progressive rock can be a very refreshing change. I like the songs that Greg Rollie sings from 1978 to 1980, but he does a great job as lead vocalist on the first three albums, including this EP. I've just always thought he had a really cool voice. I think most Journey fans would agree. This isn't as good as the next two albums, but it will work in a pinch. I won't say that this is killer material, but this Greg Rollie fronted lineup is pretty cool and interesting.
