0767903862|5.0|Bill Bryson is without doubt one of the best of modern American humorists and he does not fail to build on this reputation in his book on travels in Australia \\"In a Sunburned Country.\\"  Despite the very real problems that he outlines in his more sober discussion of the Australian aborigines, this is certainly one of the funniest books I've ever read.<br /><br />From the outback to the large cities of the only country that is also a continent, Bryson covers the essence of a land not that dissimilar from the American Southwest, where I grew up.  Yet, as he acknowledges, he has only touched on this really huge country.<br /><br />From trying to explain the significance of stromatolites to an elderly day-tripper at Shark Bay to discussing the various deadly organisms in Australia (and they have a lot!) with various companions, to traveling to really out of the way parts of the outback like Stingybark Creek, and conversely to big modern cities like Brisbane and Sydney, Bryson gives us a tantalizing glimpse of a very complex land.<br /><br />Having never been to Australia, I have to rely on the few Australian friends and acquaintances I have accumulated for my own impression.  If they are any indication, than Bryson has not painted too extreme a picture.<br /><br />Now if Bryson would only write a book on the American Southwest!  I'm sure he would find a lot of material in Arizona, New Mexico and west Texas!<br /><br />Read this book if you are at all interested in Australia or just like to read humorous travel books.  Bryson does not cover everything of interest, to be sure, but he should wet you appitite for the land down under!

B000002KKS|5.0|Okay first to clear anything the Ozzy/ early sabbath obsessives have to say, Ozzy didn't contribute anything to Sabbath when he sang for them. Butler wrote the lyrics and helped Iommi write the music. Ozzy's solo career only took off because of Randy Rhoads' (yay)outstanding talent. Early Sabbath consisted of primitive, dark 6th-string based power chords and was very simple in structure. Iommi's style gradually changed from the original Sabbath style to a bunch of stuff that all sounded the same to a far more intricate incarnation in the 80's.  <br /> <br />After ejecting Ozzy, Sabbath, now with Ronnie James Dio, produced one of the finest metal releases of all time, Heaven and Hell. Dio's voice is somewhat reminiscent of a disgruntled Freddie Mercury and helps the sound change to a sort of demonic glam metal. Iommi's guitar tone is amazing, and his riffs are vastly improved over simple, overrated licks like Iron Man and Sweet Leaf. The variety on the album is impressive, a refreshing break from many earlier albums, which all sounded practically the same. Honestly, however, the shining moment of all of Black Sabbath comes with the amazing title track, which reverts to the excellent progression of slow-fast-slow, like Stairway to Heaven or Bohemian Rhapsody. This track makes all other songs in the Sabbath catalogue seem like filler. The album is worth it solely for the song Heaven & Hell.

B000C1YL1G|5.0|\\"Curtain Call\\" is about as good a single-disc career overview of this mercurial rapper as we will ever get. <br /> <br />To feel the full force of his rage and power, you still need to listen to \\"The Marshall Mathers LP\\" all the way through, beginning to end. And probably \\"The Eminem Show\\" as well. <br />But as a document of his talent, this is pretty amazing. <br />I've always found the intertwining of his three \\"characters\\" fascinating. Is he singing as Mathers, Eminem or Slim Shady? They're NOT the same person at all. He often sings as one of them TO another. It's like climbing into the head of a psychotic schizophrenic. <br /> <br />Having said that, he is an extraordinarily talented rapper. Technically speaking, he's phenomenal. Normally song lyricists (and rap writers), when rhyming, end each line with one or two syllables that rhyme...Eminem can stretch that to four or five. Sometimes it feels as if he's rhyming entire sentences. When he off and running, it'll make you hold your breath. <br /> <br />The musical production is top-notch; it IS Dr. Dre after all, and Eminem clearly paid attention during his time with him, as his own production is fairly imaginative as well. <br /> <br />His lyrics are incendiary. Those who are easily offended should stay away.  <br /> <br />This is one angry individual. The line between autobiography, biography and fiction has never been more blurry. That's the thing: is he singing ABOUT himself, TO himself or simply telling a story? <br /> <br />He is also the rare rapper who can create massively popular singles without an ounce of compromise, \\"Without Me\\" and \\"Lose Yourself\\" being the two most obvious examples.  <br /> <br />We live in a world where Eminem has more Academy Awards than Martin Scorsese, by the way. <br /> <br />The new songs are OK, but they're simply gravy. The Elton John duet is a kick. The extra CD adds a few essential songs (\\"Kill You\\", \\"Renegade\\") with some filler. <br /> <br />If you've never heard Eminem,this is a fine place to start. If you have all the CDs already, it's nice to have all these songs in one spot...

B0007OCG4W|4.0|Closer is one of those films you have to prepare yourself for. Anyone who's seen a play that's been adapted to film will know that there's not a heckuva lot of action (this one being Patrick Marber's excellent Broadway play). But you can get some excellent dialogue and great character studies.<br /><br />Meet four screwed-up but beautiful people: Alice (Natalie Portman), an American stripper just arrived in London who gets bumped by a car; Dan (Jude Law), an obituary columnist for a local newspaper; Anna (Julia Roberts), a professional photographer who's recently divorced; and Larry (Clive Owen), a dermatologist with serious sexual issues.<br /><br />When Dan sees Alice hit by the car, he rushes to her aid and helps her to the hospital, where she's treated and released. But a strange relationship develops as the two banter back and forth with some snappy dialogue and incisive glances. Dan also knows Anna, the photographer, and is \\"in love\\" with her and tries to get her into a relationship. But when she refuses (initially) Dan and Alice move in together. But he's not through with Anna. Dan pretends to be her during an on-line chat session with Larry, the dermatologist, and asks to meet him at the London Aquarium, where Dan knows Anna visits and shoots film often. Thus, Larry makes an a$$ of himself when he first meets Anna, but they soon are entwined in a relationship, too.<br /><br />About a year later, because of Dan's persistence, Anna relents and forms a relationship with him, even though she's now married to Larry. And Larry is a bit taken with Alice (the stripper), too. Sound convoluted? It is, but it's also terribly insightful into the lives of human beings.<br /><br />______________________________________________________________________________________________<br /><br />As I stated at the beginning of this review, the movie-watcher needs to be prepared for a film like this before sitting down with it. It's not fast-paced or action driven. It's ALL ABOUT THE CHARACTERS. The awful and wonderful things we do to each other isn't candy-coated, and the language is brusque and often pornographic.<br /><br />There are also some nice little secrets about the characters that seep into the film and add a titillating surprise for those who watch CLOSER than most (for instance, check out \\"Alice's\\" passport toward the end of the film as she re-enters the United States).<br /><br />Be warned, though, this film isn't for everyone. Children and preteens should NOT watch it. Those who don't care for the vulgarities of sex-talk should also avoid it. But if you enjoy intense characters doing profound things to each other, you'll undoubtedly delight in this little flick.OUT THE CHARACTERS. B00005NWLO|3.0|Forget Lynyrd Skynyrd, if you want an example of real down home southern musicianship, get a copy of `the Fillmore Concerts\\" by the Allman Brothers Band.  Lynyrd Skynyrd has always been and will always be a watered down third rate group of Allman Brothers wannabees and this collection proves it.  While the Brothers are secretly an awesome blues & jazz group masquerading as a rock band, Skynyrd is little better than a weak attempt to replicate the Allman Brother's magic.     Whereas the Brothers use the studio versions of their songs as little more than a reference point for the live versions, Skynyrd almost never varies from the studio version.  The guitar playing lacks intensity as well as inspiration.  The keyboards are a bit better than the guitar, but still nothing to write home about.  The drumming and bass are so basic that they are barely worth noting.     If Skynyrd has anything going for them, it's the songwriting of Ronny Van Zant.  Despite being saddled with a really crappy band that wouldn't know good slide guitar playing if it snuck up and beat them in the head, Ronny was able to write some really good lyrics.  On the whole, most of his songs are honest, heartfelt and speak easily to most people.    But good lyrics alone do not a good band make, it also takes instrumental brilliance.  And that is something Skynyrd never had and isn't likely to ever get.  Pass on this one and get \\"the Fillmore Concerts\\" by the Allman Brothers instead.      Several Weeks Later:    WOW!!! Did I ever kick over a hornet's nest when I wrote this review.  I expected to start some conversation, but I had no idea that people would respond with as much vehemence as they did.  After having read some of the responses that others have posted here and stuffed into my email I now feel the need to clear some things up.    It's hard when you are trying to decide which CD's to purchase to get an objective view by only reading reviews posted by fans gushing over their pets.  While good reviews are helpful, criticism also has it's place.  I'm sorry if others find my comparison of Skynyrd and the Brothers to be unfair, but people seeking to find info on the product they are considering spending their money on have the right to hear from those who are less than impressed.    I'm sorry I didn't fall over myself for Skynyrd, but as a southerner, I am very proud of the accomplishments of southern musicians and composers, which I consider to be among the finest in the world.  I wanted the shoppers here to know that if they are interested in exploring the music of this extremely influential region that there were better places to go than mullet rockers like Skynyrd.      I'm not insecure about the status of my favorite band, the ABB, instead I just think that buyers should explore what I consider to be a better use of their music buying dollar.  Other \\"southern rock\\" live albums I would recommend before this one include,   North Mississippi Allstars: Hill Country Revue  Widespread Panic:  Live In the Classic City  Derek Trucks Band: Live at the GA Theater  Black Crows & Jimmy Page

B00003CXAW|5.0|Ray Harryhausen never forgot the first time he saw the original \\"King Kong.\\" \\"I haven't been the same since,\\" the special effects wizard of \\"Jason and the Argonauts\\" and \\"Mysterious Island\\" says. \\"That shows how a film can change a whole life sometimes.\\" Harryhausen figures he's watched the 1933 classic something like 175 times -- \\"You see something different in it every time you run it.\\" For his 176th screening, DVD viewers are invited to listen in.<br /><br />On the DVD debut of \\"King Kong,\\" Harryhausen and younger colleague Ken Ralston (\\"The Polar Express\\") spin a relaxed and often delightful commentary. At times they're experts dissecting the groundbreaking effects work; then they just seem like youngsters awed by the giant ape's sound and fury. The restored \\"King Kong\\" contains the 4 1/2 minutes that were censored as too risque or violent -- scenes such as the one in which Kong tears away some of Faye Wray's clothes. Or his size-98 foot doing the monster mash on an islander.<br /><br />The main nitrate print used for the restoration and transfer came from Britain, where \\"Kong\\" apparently roamed unmolested. The black-and-white images look sensational coming from a film that's almost 75 years old. The mono sound delivers the roars, screams and pounding drums without age-related distortion. The \\"Kong\\" DVD, with its generous suite of bonus features, completes a circle of sorts -- Criterion's laserdisc of 1985 was one of the first videos to include commentary and onscreen extras.<br /><br />The highlight, aside from the still potent 1933 film, is a chronicle of Peter Jackson's reconstruction of legendary lost \\"spider pit\\" sequence -- the missing link in the \\"Kong\\" tale. Unlike other fans, he was in the position to resurrect it -- which the director did as a side project, \\"purely for fun,\\" as he started production on the new \\"Kong.\\" The set's docu \\"RKO Production 601: The Making of Kong, Eighth Wonder of the World,\\" is well worth the time investment.

B00025ETIW|3.0|Lemme just start by saying that I by-in-large cannot stand 98% of mainstream bands.  Not because I'm closed-minded or anti-establishment but because that 98% sound just like what they are, some kind of made-to-order band in a box pushing out tunes to turn corporate revenues. Another thing I cannot stand is baseless criticism, even if its against something that deserves it. <br /> <br />MCR may be in the CD player(or MP3 player, if you're hip like you know you are.) of every 13-15 year old mallgoth within a 150 mile radius, but that doesn't make their music suck (Hahaha! Oh.. it doesn't?).  The comparisons I've seen drawn to being Sisters of Mercy or Cure immitators with Geddy Lee (Geddy LEE?!) as a vocalist are nothing but absurd and totally irrelevant. Even if you don't like them, they sound nothing like any of the above, no matter how much of a cold Geddy has, or how much vicodin the Sisters have been taking. <br /> <br />More to the point, eventhough their image comes off as being totally pretentious due in no small part to their rabid prepubescent fanbase, the music isn't half bad.  Just because a bunch of 13 year old take their songs and lyrics as holy scripture doesn't make it so, nor does it mean that's how it was intented to be taken. To me the band seems to carry a healthy sense of sardonic irony along side some otherwise cliche themes.  It seems painfully obvious that while some of the songs may certainly be heartfelt, they're not setting out to earnestly bare their innermost soul to the world on a totally sincere level. <br /> <br />The music is a thickly punk-laced machination of alternative rock, regardless of however many other miscellaneous subgenre titles you want to slap onto it to make it seem more cutting edge.  Sweet Revenge is a solid album that carries a nice sense of organic style; notably weighted to punk sensibilities, marred with melody and even dashed with the occasional guitar solo. The singer's pseudo-neurotic sarcastic sneer of a voiceis almost endearing and at times quite amusing. What this album it lacks in being truly inovative it makes up for with solid, tasteful delivery; and what else can you really ask of a mainstream band? <br /> <br />I still hate them... every time I listen to the album.

From the opening song \\"Sitting on Top of the World\\" to that point in the movie where they got on the boat.  You really got a feeling of depth to a few of these characters and you wanted to like them.   <br /> <br />The \\"three hour cruise\\" (at least it felt like one) is the part where the movie starts to slip. B00003CWPL|5.0|I accidentally watched Eraserhead many years ago on the big screen with a younger distant relative from the farmlands out West. I expected him to be creeped out and bewildered. Instead he educated me to the pretentiousness of the coasts--he roared with laughter through the whole thing! <br /> <br />Not at it, mind you, and it wasn't the nervous laughter of discomfort. He thought it was a great stitch, a merciless funny-as-hell parody on dating, getting your girlfriend (who you don't care much for to begin with) pregnant, dealing with the idiot parents, dealing with the alien baby (as all babies are for a young accidental parent), etc. Dang if my yokel cousin wasn't right and dang if most of the trendies and intellectuals oozing over this wonderful movie weren't missing the point utterly because they had very different lives, more directly in tune with John Water's nearly contemporaneous middle-class rip, Polyester. Eraserhead was working class, laboring folk stuff--it reeks of Akron, Ohio, and Wal-Mart, and homes next to decaying factories that are still, by a thread, in operation. <br /> <br />Since then I've seen this movie as it is and enjoy it as a first-rate black comedy that makes tons and tons of sense. My college friends still don't get it, after all, if the girlfriend gets pregnant it's an inconvenience that's dealt with elsewhere. None of these Ivy Leagers had ever dated the daughter of a Polish-Catholic factory worker. <br /> <br />Enjoy, but try to see this landmark comedy for what it is!

0312954468|2.0|I was a little intimidated by the fact that the author, Wilbur Smith, has written (to date) 27 novels.  Wow.  I'm still working on my first.  This is the first book of his that I have read, and I hesitate to say that although it is a well written, well plotted story of ancient Egypt with lots of action, it seemed a bit formulaic.  There is a handsome, noble hero and the young and beautiful but naive woman that he loves, the evil and perverted grand vizier, the weak-minded, vascillating Pharoah, as well as the clever, brilliant eunuch who tells the story, and dozens of lesser characters.  The problem, for me, was that the plot seemed a bit too familiar.  As soon as I read that the Pharoah's many wives had only given him daughters, I knew he would want to take the hero's love-interest to bed.  Sure enough, a few pages later, the Pharoah marries the girl.  She decides to kill herself, but is stopped by her loyal eunuch.  I felt I was reading (except for the presence of a eunuch) a modern romance novel that had been transposed to the Egypt of 3,000 years ago.  But please don't get me wrong.  I did enjoy the novel, and I admire Mr. Smith's story-telling ability.  At more than 500 pages, this is a long, leisurely, and action-packed, detail-oriented adventure story, one that has obviously been thoroughly researched.  I'm sure it can help you pass a few quiet afternoons or evenings in ancient Egypt.  Just don't expect anything more than a good adventure story.

B00005NVT1|5.0|Like the other reviewers, I will bring up this point first and foremost: this CD has one 45 minute track. B000008M54|5.0|It's hard to express what an album can mean to you. Although I have stacks of CD's, this is among the most cherished because it strikes a raw emotional chord in me that remains undiminished after years of listening. It ranks up there with Joni Mitchell's \\"Blue\\", Fleetwood Mac \\"Rumours\\", Cat Steven's \\"Tea for the Tillerman\\" and Van Morrison's \\"Moondance\\".  <br />Why? Because there are very few albums that retain their artistic value over time; a truly great album weaves a tapestry, that goes beyond a quick hit and a bunch of filler.  <br /> <br />\\"Sweet Thing\\" is the best remake of a cover song I've ever heard - it soars. All of the songs leave you feeeling as if you've been on a journey. <br />I have decided that when I die, I want \\"When Ye Go Away\\" to be played at my funeral. It evokes an image of the sea, poignant farewells, and the haunting fiddle that is just slightly buried in the mix stirs something in me that nearly makes me weep, despite having heard it hundreds of times. This CD is so precious.
